The transcript of this interview is now available on the ECB website https://t.co/mnlbMwbr7B

Lane: While our monetary policy strategy review has been inevitably delayed due to the pandemic, we are now in a position to return to this review with renewed vigour. We will take into account the additional lessons learned from the pandemic and the policy response. 5/5

Lane: The monetary policy challenge consists of two stages. First, we must counteract the negative shock to the expected inflation path. Second, our post-pandemic policy must be calibrated to ensure timely convergence to our medium-term inflation aim. 4/5
Lane: By successfully countering a tightening in financing conditions and by protecting credit supply, the measures taken have provided critical support to the economy. 3/5
Lane: Almost six months after the introduction of our measures, the evidence suggests that the policy package has stabilised markets, protected credit provision and supported the recovery. 2/5

In remarks at #JacksonHole2020, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses the monetary policy measures taken by the ECB in response to the pandemic, takes stock of the progress to date and outlines the main challenges that lie ahead. Read the speech https://t.co/C28VuNQ4Ax 1/5 https://t.co/BiRl4rEpIL

Wenn Geld über TARGET2 von einem Land in ein anderes überwiesen wird, werden die Netto-Geldströme in den Bilanzen der Zentralbanken dieser Länder erfasst. Diese im Zeitverlauf akkumulierten Geldströme sind TARGET2-Salden. https://t.co/tIzTzNQL0b

The key benchmark rates used by eurozone banks are undergoing major reforms. Banks will need to adapt in good time to the new rates regime and manage related risks. To support them, the ECB has published good practices for the transition. Read more at https://t.co/RoWIv3Xxxi https://t.co/UUjN1bNfZO

In these times of crisis, it is important that banks keep granting credit to the economy while adequately managing the heightened risks. Stable banks will be best placed to help steer the economy through the crisis. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/gkR4Bnetux https://t.co/tJXMn3aDjw

Through these swap and repo lines the ECB can provide euro liquidity to non-eurozone central banks. The arrangements provide a precautionary backstop to address euro liquidity needs outside the eurozone 2/3

What role can technological innovation play for banking supervisors? The ECB and national supervisors are exploring the potential of supervisory technology (suptech) and developing new tools to enhance day-to-day supervision. How do TARGET2 balances work and why have they been increasing over the past few years? Find out in our new explainer https://t.co/CTmbEhR8Ew

When money is sent from one country to another using TARGET2, the net flow of money is recorded on the balance sheets of their national central banks. The accumulation of these flows over time are TARGET2 balances. https://t.co/hoWsq660uC

Lane: Further progress in containing the virus will be central in determining the size and speed of the economic recovery, together with fiscal and monetary policies that are sufficiently supportive.

Read the blog post https://t.co/b2yUVQi94t 2/2

Eurostat’s preliminary flash estimate of a quarter-on-quarter decline in GDP of 12.1% makes for sobering reading, writes Chief Economist Philip R. Lane in #TheECBBlog. Together with the 3.6% decline in Q1, the cumulative decline in output in the first half of 2020 was 15.3% 1/2 https://t.co/y0SBIhb35n

The Occasional Papers address a broad audience, including analysts, academics and the interested general public. We are engaged in a range of economic research activities – find out what they are and why they are important in our explainer https://t.co/1uFP4PCWzP 2/2

This week marks 20 years since the launch of our Occasional Paper series. Since then, we’ve published over 240 papers on a variety of topics related to our tasks. Have a look at the archive https://t.co/uTuWqz9YW2 1/2

#research

Still, there has been an overall sharp decline in hiring rates and job postings due to the #containmentmeasures. Recreation, travel and manufacturing sectors are more affected than health care, software and IT services sectors. Read more https://t.co/FY5F3dUjuM 3/3

The widespread use of short-time work schemes is one of the key factors behind the overall muted immediate response of the labour market to the coronavirus crisis in the euro area. Read the full #EconomicBulletin article https://t.co/IHqjAEN4ic 2/3 https://t.co/MrZ4QyBT7v

(THREAD) A preliminary assessment shows that the coronavirus crisis has not affected employment and unemployment in the euro area as severely as expected. This sharply contrasts with the US where unemployment increased rapidly due to the pandemic 1/3 https://t.co/eBS6UdnA5O

Overall, the ECB’s measures have been an effective and efficient response to the coronavirus, and they are proportionate under current conditions in the pursuit of the ECB’s price stability mandate. Read the full article https://t.co/3kGvebYFUJ 4/4

The provision of ample central bank liquidity has helped to protect the credit flow to the real economy. For example, in the June TLTRO III operation banks bid for a total of €1,308 bn in TLTRO funds, the largest amount allotted to date under any single lending operation. 3/4

The PEPP decisions in March and June and the scaling-up of the asset purchase programme (APP) decided in March are estimated to have reduced the eurozone ten-year sovereign yield by almost 45 basis points. The measures also have a positive impact on inflation and GDP growth. 2/4

(THREAD) Our latest #EconomicBulletin examines the impact of the ECB’s monetary policy response to the #coronavirus, specifically asset purchases and the provision of central bank liquidity. 1/4 https://t.co/MaVibUYJql
Large European banks became more willing to play their intermediary role in US dollar operations, which had been disrupted by the crisis in March https://t.co/yhzvhr1lzs

The US dollar swap lines put in place between the ECB, the @federalreserve and other global central banks amid the coronavirus crisis helped the euro-dollar swap market to quickly resume its proper functioning, according to our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/yhzvhr1lzs https://t.co/UI06ljVt8h

During the lockdown many of us started to cook more at home. Our latest #EconomicBulletin shows that supply chain problems as well as stronger-than-usual demand are some of the causes of an exceptional surge in food prices in April 2020 https://t.co/Hxip95QKXe https://t.co/cqAwVjY21B
Euro area economic and financial developments by institutional sector (Q1 2020) https://t.co/vjK3yaqR8y

All our supervisory measures and actions are and will continue to be aimed at ensuring that the banking sector can remain resilient and support the economic recovery with an adequate supply of credit, emphasises Andrea Enria https://t.co/fw4IbOxpGi 4/4

The same applies for replenishing the liquidity coverage ratio. The ECB will consider both bank-specific and market-specific factors when establishing the timeline for banks to rebuild their liquidity buffers 3/4 https://t.co/pft8XU7dMv

Banks will not be required to start replenishing their capital buffers before the peak in capital depletion is reached, which is expected to happen in 2022. This should allow banks to continue supporting economic growth and lending 2/4

We have taken measures to mitigate the risk of simultaneous deleveraging and procyclical behaviour, and we are extending the recommendation on distributions and buybacks until January 2021 https://t.co/IMNbzvZ103 1/4 https://t.co/046RxirDjD

If the situation worsens, authorities must stand ready to implement further measures to prevent simultaneous deleveraging by banks, which could deepen the recession and severely hit their asset quality and capital positions https://t.co/MDZLV9wv92 2/2

The results of the ECB’s vulnerability analysis of directly supervised banks show that they can withstand pandemic-induced stress. The results also help provide new information on the likely path back to normality, writes Andrea Enria in a blog post https://t.co/AHVFWeSiP6 1/2 https://t.co/SNIXrmSXFd

Our latest #EconomicBulletin says that GVC spillovers could intensify the decline in world trade. In the longer term, the disruption may lead to a review of processes and a substantial return of production and sourcing closer to the final market https://t.co/wdKKWxeyLt 2/2

(THREAD) World trade has been falling sharply on the back of the #coronavirus pandemic. Disruptions to global value chains (GVCs) have exposed the interdependence of countries in terms of the supply of inputs and final goods in a way we have never seen before 1/2 https://t.co/yJkzKsSFCZ

The success of this turning point will depend on the policies adopted by each European country. There is a chance to use European funds to modernise the economy and make it greener, more digitalised and more inclusive. Read more https://t.co/tROf3N4ekT 4/4

The approval of the recovery fund shows awareness of the need for a common response, and the benefits – for all – of providing it. Recovery in any one part of the eurozone has positive effects on growth and jobs throughout it  3/4

The ECB’s measures were needed to prevent financial fragmentation and safeguard the monetary policy transmission mechanism. We have supported consumption and investment by households and businesses, protecting the productive capacity of the economy 2/4

(THREAD) European institutions, including the ECB, have provided a European response to a European problem, Executive Board member Fabio Panetta tells @Repubblica. By acting together, we’ve generated a “European dividend” https://t.co/tROf3N4ekT 1/4 https://t.co/HbXvNehKaA

The agreement on the EU recovery fund sends a strong message for the exit from the crisis, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos in an interview with El Independiente. The funding will focus on climate change and digitalisation

Based on the analysis, we have identified some of the areas of focus for our supervisory work moving forward, including assessing the collective suitability of bank’s boards in terms of their IT expertise and whether banks comply with regulation on outsourcing 3/3
Banks reported that their weakest areas were data quality management and IT risk management. In some cases, banks incurred losses due to the unavailability or poor quality of outsourced services 2/3
